intro: Galium vernum var. hirsutum, commonly known as hairy bedstraw, is a flowering plant in the Rubiaceae family. It is a low-growing perennial that features slender, hairy stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white or pale yellow flowers in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its hairy texture and delicate appearance make it a distinctive member of the bedstraw genus.
